data.name: Social Media Can Help Track Tornadoes, But Was That Tweet Real?

data.message: I thought you said a tomato was coming!
Reading any of the comments here will give a good idea of how useless social media happens to be. Good luck.
But does anybody really care about a storm out in the middle of nowhere? Damage will be relatively minimal.

That's a recipe for disaster. 

Nothing can be ok online unless identity confirmation is established. Anything to do with  social networks has to take into account the "a-hole troll factor" which is always there, always present and lacks all morals and reason.  All it takes is one (and I have seen this) to make an avalanche out of a spec of snow, specially via Twitter.

The only good social media is, to me, when talking about the weather is getting me to look at a current radar map for the official data.  Some info coming through on Facebook is regularly too old to help me.

Social media can and should be only one component of tracking a storm and notifying the public.  Living in northern Illinois, but not in the path of that huge tornado, the news coverage was continuous during the event with part of the real-time info coming from cell phones and social media.  It certainly helped the weather and news dudes keep everyone informed that day.

data.caption: www.npr.org
data.message:
Of course, not everything tweeted turns out to be true. 

Plus, tweeters skew young and urban, making Twitter storm data less useful for rural areas.
data.description: Researchers at Purdue are using software to mine tweets for data that can help warn that a dangerous storm is approaching. But the data may not always be reliable and analyzing it can be tricky.

My mother was a healthy person. Never smoked or drank alcoholic beverages, ate the right kinds of food, exercised weekly, lost a lot of weight. She ended up dying do to complications of Lung Cancer at the age of 62. She didn't even know she had cancer until she was hospitalized for a procedure to see what was happening in her lungs. She never fully recovered after that and passed a week later after leaving the hospital. 

I feel like the information we get about Cancer from the media is inaccurate and is only used to create an anti-smoking message which is now morphed into an pro healthy diet message. Well heathy people who never smoked get and pass from Cancer too.

Making healthy choices doesn't mean you won't get cancer, heart disease, or others illnesses. But science has proven that you will be less likely to get those diseases.
So.... republican states are unhealthy as a whole.  Let's cut all Healthcare In those states to let them die off.

Peach and apricot seeds and extracts, vitamin b 17. Medical marijuana oil. AlkAline revitalization.  Noni juice.  Onions and mushrooms, and many other, alternative cures,  news ignore researching while posting the accepted lies.

I was just diagnosed with cancer in January at the age of 47. I am a healthy eater, I am fit and exercise 6-7 days a week, I have never smoked, and rarely drink alcohol. Did it prevent cancer .... No. You can't fully prevent cancer; BUT you can make lifestyle choices to HELP prevent cancer. What I have learned is that being healthy helped me get thru the surgery and treatment easier than if I had been unhealthy. I was strong and healthy and didn't have other health risks as I approached major surgery. It made that part so much easier. These are recommendations that they know help, not guarantees. But why wouldn't you do everything possible to keep yourself healthy and possibly prevent disease which certainly helps when illness strikes.

As mentioned by some posters here, there should've been a map showing the total  rates for each state, so we can see if these causal factors seemingly result in more cases of cancer.  Also, the writer's statement "While a cure for cancer remains elusive..." is misleading.  First, there isn't just ONE cancer, there are myriad.  Second, some ("many?") cancers ARE indeed cured, and oncologists do use that term with their patients.

Cancer has been around since man kind took it's first steps, probably even before that in other animals. Cancer is in our makeup. There are things we can do to fight it (eat clean, smoke pot, exercise, etc) but unfortunately at the end of the day, it's just a damn crapshoot.
I love being vegan and eating both 5 servings of veggies per day and also 5 servings of fruit.

I'm amazed at how many people refuse to heed the all knowing that processed foods, additives, preservatives, etc. are not normal for our bodies, therefore harming our bodies and  will continue to consume them without even batting an eye. Your voice could change things. Educate yourselves. Bad stuff is in everything, demand better.
Hey. How about pollution of air and water?  Don't let big corporations off the hook.
Cure for most is in a non-acidic environment for the body...
The darkest states on this map are also some of the poorest in the country with the least amount of environmental protection from industrial polluters.

Getting rid of pollutants (in all their varied forms) would also help prevent cancer; and wearing sunscreen and hats in the case of melanoma. Note, some of the darkest states on the map are oil and coal producing states, but I'm sure there are other toxins at play. They're also those who historically skimp on preventative care.

You can really tell how well the marketing machine has worked in this country by the amount of "Who eats vegetables for breakfast!?" comments. Breakfast is a made up meal, there isn't actually a rule that says you shouldn't be eating steak and lobster then. And the REAL incredulous-question should be "Who eats cake for breakfast!?"- oh right, we do. Pop-Tarts, donuts, sugary cereals, sugary yogurt and pre-packaged "fruit" oatmeals and "breakfast bars"... But the person who adds broccoli and spinach to their scrambled eggs is the weirdo? Man do we have things backwards.

Notice the maps...  Clearly those states have poor health outcomes, but they also face staggering environmental degradation. When will we step back from only focusing on personal health risks and look at the role environment plays on cancer?

Marijuana helps with the side effects. Get real people...don't you think if pot  cured cancer, people like Steve Jobs or Pavarotti would have been smoking it. It's not a cure, but it does help with Side Effects. People are so into wanting pot to be this miracle cure. I wish it was. I've known many of people who smoked it everyday since they were teenagers, they still got Cancer or COPD. I also wish Martinis and red wine were cures. Too much of anything, not enough of the essential like vegetables, is a bad thing.
I would like to see adult cancer rates by state represented in the same manner. Do the states with the highest risk factors also have the highest rates?  I am thinking no...

People need to realize there will never be a cure for cancer. All we can hope for is better screening and prevention and the development of better chemotherapeutics. Cancer is a complicated, heterogeneous entity and articles like this only propagate the idea that a silver bullet solution is possible.

NPR---important reporting, but there's an error in your fruit and vegetable graphs. Review the shading in the fruit and vegetable graphs. Either the caption or the shading scale is incorrect. Caption says darker shading represents "The percentage of adults who reported eating less than the recommended fruit servings per day" (ie, not good). The graph shading, however, indicates lower percentages of "not good" (ie, 0%-21%) in states such as Louisiana. I'm sure the opposite is intended.

data.caption: www.npr.org
data.message:
While a cure for cancer remains elusive, we already know how to keep many cases of the disease from developing in the first place: Cut out risk factors, like smoking, obesity, lack of exercise and poor diet.

But many of those preventable risk factors remain common. For example, only 15 percent of adults report eating three or more servings of vegetables each day.
data.description: The prevalence of smoking and other major cancer risk factors varies widely by state. So does the uptake for preventive screening tests.

The Triple Axel is the Everest of women's figure skating, both terrifying and compelling. The only jump that starts on the forward foot, it explodes in 31/2 revolutions -- yet demands a delicate touch on takeoff and iron strength on landing.

Tonya Harding became the first U.S. woman to land the jump in competition when she completed it 45 seconds into her free skate at the 1991 U.S. championships. The second young woman to land the triple axel was cute and bouncy teenager, 15 year old Kimmie Meissner on January 15, 2005. She finished third place after landing the triple axel during the U.S. Figure Skating Championships here in Portland, Oregon.

data.name: Jon Krakauer Tells A 'Depressingly Typical' Story Of College Town Rapes

data.message: Lucky, it may happen on rare occasions that a woman lies about rape. rare occasions.  Why would your average college girl put herself through the awful experience of a rape trial just to get even? Her life is ruined. His goes on as if nothing happened. Unless he's convicted, which is hard to do.

Let's do a little experiment. "Like" this comment if you or someone you personally know was a victim of sexual violence and didn't report it. "Reply" if you or someone you personally know have lied about being raped, or have been falsely accused of rape.

Thank you for writing about this.  This is my University, and I can tell you many students were disgusted by how the administration handled sexual assault during my time there. One of the most frightening things about our culture is how under-prosecuted and under-punished rapists are, and how everyone rushes to defend the rapist and demonize the victim for "ruining his/her life". No, they were responsible for their own ruination when they decided to rape.
The overwhelming majority don't report rape, because they're in shock and feel like it was somehow their fault - and they don't want to have anything more to do with the rapist.

None of the false allegations negate rape victims' experiences. Rape is an act of violence. The fact that the majority of rapes are committed by men, and the low number of prosecutions, demonstrates the imbalance of power, entitlement, and privilege.

I'm glad to see a national discussion about rape - one prompted by an excellent author and covered in a professional way by NPR. 

And it's still slightly distressing to me that this discussion is likely to go farther and become more meaningful because it's been prompted by the findings of a male writer. Not to say that men don't experience rape, but most victims are women. And yet, when women write about rape, too often the national discussion becomes about the author, rather than her work. 

People ask if she was raped, or if she's telling the truth about rape, or they say she's exaggerating the problem or being "shrill" or that she simply hates men. None of those things is likely to be said about Jon Krakauer. Nor should they be about any other researcher/authors who would write about the epidemic of rape in the US.

data.name: Live At Guitar Center: A Lot Of Noise And A Little Fun

data.message: Guitar Center/Musician's "friend"/WoodwindBrasswind/Music & Arts..... all the same company. In the business of putting every other music store out of business. Shop local, support your community and save your money. We beat GC on a regular basis. Jim's Music Center
I've never heard more E and G power chords in my life than I heard on one Friday night at Guitar Center
Where's the special guest appearance by unbuttoned-too-far-western-shirt guy attempting GnR solos, or the bonus track feat. Backwards-Monster-Energy-Hat Rage Against The Machine Riff Guy?

"I think another unspoken rule is if you are really good, you kind of have to pump the brakes a little bit on showing off," Wall says. "It kind of reminds me also of a watering hole where all these different animals go from different levels of the food-chain, and while they're there they suspend trying to eat each other." Certainly not all days are like that.
Once in the Union Sq GC, there was a grand piano in the vintage room. I was  playing something through a Brown Princeton. A teenaged girl sat at the piano and started playing the theme from The Godfather, REALLY WELL, using a book.
I stopped, because how often does someone get a crack at big gorgeous piano in that place? And it was nice hearing something melodic, from a BIG, real piano, rather than a faux overdriven guitar. It was just cool to hear that piano.
She said I didn't have to stop, like she'd interupted me.  
I started doing moody, forlorn little organized crime volume swells with plenty of tremolo. It was a really enjoyable jam.
Guitar Centers are terrible ~soulless~ places...the Sam's Club of music only without discounted prices.  Small, "non-corporate" music stores are ALWAYS superior.

Our mom & pop music store has been going head-to-head with Guitar Center for 18 years: we're still here and GS is slowly twisting in the corporate wind.  Personal, intuitive service is the key; real musicians value it.  GS' whole philosophy: take the amateurs' money & run!
So, this guy made an album by secretly recording the sounds that other people made. More soulless than Guitar Center.
Yup.  He got the obligatory bass player slapping the shit out of an instrument in a non-musical way..

My son and his friend spent many hours "testing" the equipment at Guitar Center as teens.  Got some good equipment there and met some great people.   Developed a hobby he loves and after graduating from law school still jams with his friends.   

Thank you Guitar Center.

I hate Guitar Center. It's like Wal-Mart for musical instruments. The employees are usually half wits that couldn't answer a technical question if their lives depended on it.  And their Luthier maybe, just maybe, can intonate a guitar on his best day. Their guitar are beat up from strays walking in and playing them over and over again. The only thing they are good for is if you need strings. They are handy if you want to try out a guitar first before you order it from Sweetwater.
Guitar Center: hell on earth.

Wish You Were Here.
B|

Gee, the story was about the people at G.C. not the chain itself.   By the way,  a lot of store owners are just rude and very arrogant.  I had a Fender dealer refuse allow me to play an American Telecaster,  needless to say I went elsewhere.
stole music and took credit, received praise.

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9ed0wyjnlLI

Not all of us that work, or have worked at a GC are shitty people. I fought long and hard to make sure I was the very best friend of any customer I had at GC, and many other member of my crew did the same, please understand I also think that there's a lot that could be better but remember when your slamming the company and every facet of GC, just remember these are all music lovers like you and a lot of us are genuinely here to enjoy a musically social and cultural experience. All of my worst experiences at guitar center aren't the ones where the super douchey salesperson tried to sell me a guitar I didn't like or need, it was when the customer laughed in my face and treated me and my other good friends and associates like garbage without even speaking with us for five minutes first.

I miss the classics...I always sought and bought a Public enemy Cd or Chuck Ds later solo work first before any other hip hop cd. The production and sound not just the rap was a big part of why they are my favorite still to this day.

BRING THE NOISE, BASS FOR YO FACE!

Public Enemy was one of those groups that was light years ahead of their musical peers and landscape; their talent (individual and cumulative) as well as their producers' talent was immeasurable. 

Lyrics, energy...rap was a genre that was spoken, felt, and absorbed and they were artists with a canvas. 

It's a shame some still see them as "just a rap group." Their impact brought about social change, caused many to question societal injustices, and launched the careers of men who made their mark.
We need Public Enemy more now than ever.
It was one of a kind 360 degree quadrasound brilliance.
As a disco kid, house music lover, PE, ATCQ, Gangstarr pulled me deeper into hip hop after the Sugar Hill Gang era BECAUSE of those thick, layered, productions WITH deep lyrics on top. Respect.
Genius production.
They and the message they brought are needed again now more than ever...

data.caption: npr.org
data.message: People often refer to the multi-layered, cacophonous style of Public Enemy's production team the Bomb Squad as a "wall of noise," but to let Squad member Hank Shocklee tell it, their sample-heavy approach was more akin to a particular collage-based visual artist's.
data.description: Public Enemy producer Hank Shocklee talks about hip-hop's often overlooked influence on technology and the current state of the genre with Microphone Check.

the irony it wasn't available to the blind to begin with is hilarious

data.caption: www.npr.org
data.message:
The FCC requires broadcasters to provide audio descriptions of many programs so blind people can enjoy TV along with everyone else.

But Netflix isn't a broadcaster.
data.description: The series stars a blind superhero — but at first, it lacked audio descriptions for the visually impaired. Netflix has added that option, but the issue raises larger questions of online accessibility.
